intro: Pseudosecale villosum var. glabratum, commonly known as the smooth false sparrowgrass, is a perennial grass species native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and narrow, grass-like leaves that are typically glabrous or nearly hairless. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences with pale green to yellowish flowers, which bloom in early spring. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and open plains. Its botanical features make it an important component of local ecosystems, supporting various insect and bird populations.
